job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Detroit, MI
pros: Valuable Experience: As a Graduate Teaching Assistant, you have the opportunity to gain valuable teaching experience, which is essential for a career in academia. Networking Opportunities: You will have the chance to work closely with faculty members and other professionals in your field, which can help you build valuable connections and expand your professional network. Financial Benefits: In addition to gaining valuable experience, Graduate Teaching Assistants receive a stipend, which can help to offset the cost of tuition and other expenses. Flexibility: Many Graduate Teaching Assistant positions offer flexible schedules, allowing you to balance your work and academic responsibilities. Professional Development: Wayne State University offers a variety of professional development opportunities for Graduate Teaching Assistants, including workshops, seminars, and conferences, which can help you grow as a teacher and scholar.
cons: Heavy Workload: Graduate Teaching Assistants often have a heavy workload, which can include teaching multiple classes, grading papers, and holding office hours. This workload can be overwhelming, particularly when combined with your own academic responsibilities. Limited Control: As a Graduate Teaching Assistant, you may not have as much control over course content and teaching methods as you would if you were the primary instructor. This can be frustrating if you have a particular teaching style or approach you want to use. Limited Job Security: Graduate Teaching Assistant positions are often temporary, and you may need to reapply for the position each semester or academic year. This can create uncertainty about your job prospects and financial stability. Limited Benefits: Graduate Teaching Assistants may not receive the same benefits as full-time faculty members, such as health insurance or retirement benefits. Professional Pressure: As a Graduate Teaching Assistant, you may feel pressure to balance your responsibilities as a teacher and a student while also trying to establish yourself as a competent and capable professional in your field. This can be challenging and stressful at times.

review_title: The Good & the Not So Good
pros:
The benefits are truly unparalleled. Zero deductible on medical insurance & 200% match on retirement plan. Where else can you get that these days.
The university is also very proactive about social justice & diversity.
cons:
This is a very old University (founded in the 1800’s). Some leaders have been with the university a VERY long time & are old fashioned & inflexible about things like remote work post-pandemic. They will need to modernize and update their policies & practices unless they want a mass exodus.

Pay increases are scarce to nonexistent, so make sure you negotiate a good starting salary. If you’re non-represented, you may never get another increase. The last 2 years, only union employees have received base pay increase. Unless you have a union negotiating your pay, don’t expect many increases.

Another drawback: the university is VERY bureaucratic, with levels upon levels of management.

review_title: Wayne State can be a good place to work
pros:
Great vacation time, decent salary, 403(b) investment options and matching are nice, good insurance benefits, 37.5hr work week, semi-flexible work environment, salaried but overtime eligible (which is kind of weird), professional development opportunities (conferences and workshops).

The department I was in was very progressive and the team was awesome. Working with other units on campus was a mixed bag, some were on top of things, others seemed very disorganized.
cons:
Pay increases are minimal, not much room for growth, parking isn't covered by employer (but isn't as expensive as parking in other major cities, so not too bad).

Most tech jobs are unionized; for some positions this might be good, but for professional staff this hinders advancement, creates a less than professional atmosphere, and the whole concept of "bumping" is horrible for niche skill professional positions (random other tech staff person can't do a web developer's job just because their base title is also "System Integrator II"); this shouldn't be happening the way it does.

pros: Prior to the UPTF-AFT organizing the adjunct/part-time faculty at Wayne State, an instructor usually found out only a week or so prior to the semester starting, whether they had a teaching assignment. Obviously this was stressful and the pay rates were well below average. Thankfully a number of part-time faculty took it upon themselves to start organizing, and after a number of years and enough signatures, the union was recognized. Since then it's been much better. Unfortunately, due to state budgets being cut, many department programs which used part-time faculty have been reduced. The school itself has worked to improve access to best practice teaching methods and technology with investments in The Teaching Commons technology research center and The Office of Teaching and Learning and has worked to improve communication and resource availability with part-time faculty as well.
cons: Varying degrees of resources provided to part-time faculty across departments including office space, photocopying accessibility and basic technology and technical support. Parking is still a premium on campus and compensation for parking, time on campus for office hours/student support, departmental training and other benefits is still sub-par.

pros: Calm environment, most of the people are friendly
cons: No time off for first 6 months, accrue points and get penalized  for approved sick time

review_title: Stable working environment, yet aggravating higher management.
pros: The benefits package for the University sort of offsets the lower salary a licensed professional would expect. The time off and stability make it all tolerable. I generally work with very nice people, who mostly have the better interest of the University in mind, and whom care about their work.
cons: There are many double standards practiced, contrary to any written Policy and Procedure. The CFO seems to be the most detached with wage, basing it on a production industry. The trend and perception seems to be that newly solicited professionals will be reviewed for appropriate market driven salaries, but consideration to rite the wrongs of previous offers will not be considered.

pros: Great benefits with 10% match and more vacation days than you know what to do with plus they have an excellent Wellness program with a fitness center on campus.
cons: No upper management with any goals to work towards.  My immediate supervisor doesn't like to work so is threatened by any fresh ideas or enthusiasm and will make me look bad to upper management (with no goals) if I dare work too hard.  No innovation . . . not even a glimpse towards competing with on-line courses.  Lots of people getting paid to do nothing and way too many unions protecting them.  Silos everywhere so there's no interfacing between departments.  In 3 years I've received $600 in raises (total).  But the cost of parking has gone up twice.  If you want to get paid to play Candy Crush, this is a great place to work.

review_title: Borderline hostile work environment but good benefits
pros: Very good medical benefits. Nice office furniture.
cons:
The environment is highly unprofessional among the staff.  The work environment allows "cliques" to form and lead others to feel ostracized.  Most managers started at WSU and have never left.  There is little training of managers and many are openly abusive to staff. If managers consider themselves “trained,” it is because they took classes AT WSU toward a business degree (but have worked at no other "business."

There is no plan or outline for employee advancement or growth.  You will find that nepotism is very obvious.  Someone always seems to be someone’s brother or sister, best friend or mother.  It’s a very inbred environment. Managers seldom assist in helping their subordinates to grow or move into higher positions at the University (unless refer to nepotism critique).

review_title: Dysfunctional Work Environment, Hiring is done by a network of cronyism and nepotism
pros: Good medical benefits and vacation time.
cons:
Management encourages intimidation:
1.	Managers are remote from employees
2.	The intimidator is part of management “club”
3.	Management seems to deal with the intimidator/s
4.	Intimidation is rewarded
5.	Effort to appease a workplace intimidator

Intimidating and manipulative behavior by management and (higher ranking workers) is the norm rather than the exception. Dysfunctional relationships among employees is the norm.
 Gossip and criticism are the standard, where cliques lead to favoritism and feuding. Hiring is done by a network of cronyism and nepotism. There are no clear objectives in many functions, so it can be tough to determine what’s important and what isn’t

Incompetent or or powerless human resource department:
Human resource (“HR”) managers are either unable or unwilling to deal with rampant workplace intimidation, rule violations, or poor hiring practices.

review_title: Frustrating work environment, but good for experience, education
pros:
Great benefits. They're generous with vacation, and almost everyone gets small cost of living raises each year. 
Full time employees can take up to 4 or 6 credits for free each semester depending on their category. 
Very, very hard to get fired, so there's good job security.
cons:
Low salary compared to other jobs that require the same level of skill.
Very little opportunity for advancement. 
Bullying. Not all high level administrators are needlessly mean, but many are. If you ask around in any department, people can tell you who the bullies are and how toxic their behavior is. Unfortunately, there's no institutional response to bad behavior unless it's racist or sexist, so bulling continues unabated. Your experience at Wayne will vary based on how many of these toxic people you have to deal with and how often. 
Terrible internal communication makes it very hard to do anything but routine work.

pros:
Wayne State is a great place to work if you're motivated to be innovative and build networks quickly.  

The benefits are great, some of the best in the area including 403b, wellness warriors, vacation, insurance, and best of all winter break!

Colleagues are willing to share information and help you with challenges.

It's a very diverse environment, people are not afraid to talk about difficult subjects.
cons:
There are not clear career paths so you have to create your own direction. 

Faculty treat staff horribly, like we are the hired help.  Deans can range from really cool to evil narcissistic overlords, they change about every 4 years so it's a gamble.

review_title: Diverse, and not the way you think
pros:
I remember coming here originally as a student, and being so thrilled to have found a good school with ordinary, middle-class kids who were doing well. I came from a very snooty school and always felt out of place there. Here, I found people from all walks of life, and so many different cultures. 

This is a place where people have to work hard to study and in their jobs. The good old boy system really doesn't work here. As someone who works here, 

I really appreciate that women and minorities are in leadership positions.
cons: This is a big university, and we are working at making things more user-friendly, and less bureaucratic.

review_title: A good place to work but like most higher ed, rife with red tape.
pros: Excellent benefits, tuition assistance, generous time off for assorted reasons (illness, vacation, holidays), holiday closure between Christmas and New Year's, campus life, access to training, access to education and information, a lot of nice people who have longevity.
cons: Yearly cutbacks in departments, frequent hiring freezes university-wide, bureaucracy and departments designed to handle bureaucracy, high parking fees for employees, disorganized review process, union bumping in many departments after layoffs, "we've always done it this way" attitude.

pros: I received a generous salary and teaching load (1-1 for the first two years, 2-1 for the next three) offer and have had consistent summertime employment, if desired. My colleagues are genuinely good people to work with, and I feel part of my college's research community. Wide variety of affordable housing options both in the city and in the suburbs, depending on what you're looking for. Lots of "after school" and weekend activities in the metro Detroit area. Eight months of the year have relatively pleasant weather.
cons: Detroit continues to experience challenges stemming from the economic crisis. My house has lost value since I purchased it. Winter can be bleak, especially if you come from sunnier southern climes.

job_title: Graduate Student Assistant in Detroit, MI
pros: The pay is good and  if you are full time you get tuition benefits.
cons:
There are many cliques.  Many times, getting and keeping a job at at WSU is more dependent on who you know or who you are connected to rather than your ability or even qualifications.


Many in senior management are more concerned with solidifying their power bases by stacking their staff with friends and  relatives. The search for quality and excellence is subjugated to the desire for control of personal fiefdoms. 

There are a lot of internecine battles between senior staff members and junior staff, if they are not careful, can find themselves in the middle of it, to their detriment.

I have seen several good people leave Wayne because of this culture.

review_title: Been at WSU in a few capacities...
pros:
Great opportunities for collaboration, inquiry, research and making an impact.
Exposure and a chance to work with some amazing and bright colleagues!
Excellent benefits including tuition reimbursement, retirement matching, medical benefits and more.
Opportunities for lateral and upward mobility.
Great vacation time to provide work-life balance.
cons:
The organization lacks structured organizational management/leadership training and human resources support.

There is a large gap of skills and knowledge between the upper management/deans and workers. There should be training programs to close these gaps to increase overall operational efficiency and productivity.

The organization as a whole is slightly old fashion. Workers are regarded as useful if they are at a desk and not measured by productivity/value of work.  If in administration, working from home or flex-schedule is not really an option.

review_title: Defined career paths and salary ranges - Union loopholes used by management removes job security.
pros: Unionized IT jobs allow you some protection and job security once you are through the probation period.  Also has defined and very clear promotion paths including salary ranges in lieu of having the union.
cons: Unions are not taken seriously, management simply uses loopholes to eliminate positions.  Very much an insiders club when it comes to promotions and hiring.  Like a lot of places out there, it's who you know more so than what you know.  Results in a lot of poor decisions made by management as employees are, from what I've witnessed, simply telling management what they want to hear.

review_title: If you just want to sit around all day...
pros: Nice long holiday breaks, snow days off.  Honestly, hard to think of any ... If you have kids they can go to college at WSU for 1/2 off. Boss was oblivious to people taking fake sick days off.
cons: I worked here for 5 months. The job was horrible. No work to be done, all fellow employees were so miserable as they had been there for 10 years and hardly making 40k. The starting pay is low, even if you have a Master's. Also they make their employees shell out $80 a month for parking. Manager was horrible and offensive to co-workers. This job is good for someone who just wants to kill time  on the computer all day and listen to miserable people complain.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Scientist in Detroit, MI
pros: Pretty good benefits. Work flexibility.
cons:
I'm a postdoc -- salary is not great, but it's not great in most places. Haven't had any kind of raise in 3 years. HR is a nightmare. They never took my retirement contribution out even though they had necessary paperwork and i was given the run around from months trying to get that figured out. Most of the people in administrative positions could care less about what they do. 

No maternity leave. YOu get 12 weeks through FMLA -- burned through all of my vacation and sick days.

review_title: The Lonely Life of an Adjunct Instructor
pros: The only reason for agreeing to teach in remote outreach centers is engaging with the students, in particular the returning student. I liked teaching at night because of the mature students who were making sacrifices to improve their writing and their comprehension. I always provided food and encouraged the students to share with me. Wayne State is a large enterprise, but I always felt that the other adjuncts were qualified and conscientious.
cons: The isolation from the English Department and full-time faculty was a problem for me. Teachers like to share, but since adjuncts teach at hours that full-time professors would not find acceptable, there was very little camaraderie.

job_title: Lab Technician Senior in Detroit, MI
pros: The hours are lenient, the atmosphere relaxed and there is a lot to learn. They were pretty much willing to work around my part time grad class schedule as long as I was available and prepared for labs.
cons: Working with professors and students requires you to be on your mental toes much of the day so must be good with people.

pros: Daily exposure to print media, Client interaction, and corporate level design and branding standards. Really relaxed schedule—you basically get to pick your shift during the open hours. The sense of community is also strong, Expect weekly rundowns with the other designers to figure out what is working, what we all can do to reduce stress, and how we can be more efficient. A lot of technical design practice, Management is really nice and understanding as well.
cons: Maxed at 20 hours a week due to student status, and it's not enough on its own to afford midtown Detroit. Client oriented work, so do not expect to create anything groundbreaking or experimental, it's much more design than it is art.

review_title: This has been a roller coaster ride with constant changes in administration.
job_title: University Counselor III in Detroit, MI
pros: Wayne has a great tuition benefits package, good health benefits, dental, and vision.  In addition, they have a generous contribution to our 401k plans.
cons: The management is inconsistent with respect to equal and fair treatment among its emplooyees.  You can be a slacker and get the same rewards and perks as a person who is dedicated and has a strong work ethic.  It is almost impossible to advance in many positions without going through a lengthy and time consuming professional advancement process.

pros: The benefits package is very good. The wellness warrior program is excellent.
cons:
The practice of hiring and promoting friends and family before others  is widespread. If you are not related to a senior staff member or if you are not their good buddy, you have very little chance of getting a good position. And if by chance you do get hired, you can forget promotions unless you join  the the right "click" at Wayne.

Because of the power of the clicks and and the lack of action by the executive administration to stop these practices,  It is a very difficult work environment if you are not in a click. There is a lot of exclusion and information is hoarded within the click and groups.

Stressful work environment.

job_title: Office Services Clerk, Lead in Detroit, MI
pros:
Working at Wayne State University provides an abundance of good sound employment opportunity's.  The opportunity is surpassed, only by the beautiful college environment right in the middle of the Metro Detroit Area.

I could go on for hours about the University, ranked 43 out of over 400 national institutions of higher learning, for research.  Competence and professionalism are hallmarks of the faculty.  So, be you faculty, staff or students you can't go wrong at Wayne State.
cons: A couple pet peeves of mine while employed there was at peak rush hour periods, mobility can be difficult.  It can be difficult logistically when it snows over 6 inches.  Those are minor complaints considering the magnitude of the University's responsibilities.

pros: Full-time position has health insurance and other benefits.
cons: Financial Aid Officer is the lowest pay in the entire department. The FAO's have the highest turnover rate of any job I have ever seen due to low morale & unmanageable work load. Unreasonable expectations set by management with absolutely no training given and even less support! One-stop welcome center concept is a joke. By the time students get back to see a FAO, they are very frustrated and have been back several times & told to "allow for processing time." The job of FAO is a contracted one, with management deciding whether to renew your contract or not, with a maximum of 5 years. Worst place to work, ever. Run while you can!

review_title: Who you know is more important than skills (nepotism).
pros: Benefits are good. Health, dental, vision. Can take classes for free. About 75% of staff is pleasant to work with.
cons: Must pay for parking. Bathroom facilities are not kept well. Not uncommon for tenured faculty to treat staff poorly. Pay is not competitive- You will always start at the "lowest pay" in the job description. Upward mobility is based on who you know, not on performance. Staff do not receive the budgetary support they need while faculty are provided nearly limitless amounts of money (regardless of whether or not they intend to be responsible with it).

review_title: Fantastic training, if your advisor has close ties to the medical school and clinical settings.

pros:
Excellent faculty
Clinical access - translational focus
Multidisciplinary departments
Cutting edge technology (depends on department)
School of Medicine is ranked and well-respected
cons: Detroit is decent place to work, but it has its negative stereotypes (which are often true), and decent living will almost always require a 30 min commute. Infrastructure is the most limiting feature.

pros: The diversity and exposure to the ever changing workforce. Students come from all four corners of the world but have chosen Wayne state as their place for opportunity and growth. It's a great shool and you have the opportunity to continue your education.
cons: With the diversness within the school itself, you still find a bit of racism-even after having an African American President. Some of the old gaurd that's there need to give it up and retire. While many in academia represent the various cultures, it's not always so within management. Unfortunatley, in my school, it's people seem to think it's acceptable to express them selves.  That makes for a depressing environment.

review_title: Resident Advisor: Review based on Housing Department
pros:
Flexible work hours that accommodate class schedules.
Professional development.
Positive coworker relationships.
cons:
Poor management: poor planning, apparent incompetence at times
Two-faced management: say they're here to support and help us, but won't help if it means extra work for them
No income: compensated with housing and  meal plan, so no income. Not allowed to work elsewhere on campus and off campus work allowance is very limited.
Occasionally required to do work that is not part of the job.

review_title: There are some issues, but get treated better than a lot of other graduate schools from what I hear.
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Detroit, MI
pros: Great benefits - the graduate student union makes sure we have the same benefits as the faculty and staff.  There are some great research and collaboration  opportunities if you know where to look.  There is usually funding to be had - I've been funded through GTA, GRA, and fellowships for the 5 years I've been here.
cons: Dealing with administration is a chore - very slow and inefficient.  You have to take a lot of classes - more than the norm.

job_title: Lead Applications Technical Analyst in Detroit, MI
pros: Great benefits, awesome area to work and getting better every day.  If you are a self-starter you can get a ton done and this job can be very satisfying.
cons: Worked over 10 years without a promotion, no merit increases, mutually beneficial blame scenario between management and union.  If you rely on sound policy and direction to do good work, you might find WSU a difficult place to work.

pros: Good pay for part-time work. Own desk space in windowed, shared office. Independence in running of classes as long as results meet expectations.  Friendly co-workers. Access to copy room with full-sized fridge, microwave and coffee maker. Professional development available from university on your own time.
cons: Taxed on "free" parking in structure. No reviews of performance by peers or supervisors. Little encouragement of academic or professional development. Little opportunity to have informal water cooler conversation or lunch with co-workers. No community feeling with students.

pros:
Many people don't want to live in Detroit, so it is easier to get into programs
PIs higher rated than you would expect
Area is improving a lot from when I started
Pay is competitive
Close to downtown
cons:
Buildings are spread out
Difficult to deal with administration for the graduate school
Registering for classes and PhD credits is a pain
Hard to get a job in the area post graduation if that is your intent
Many comuters

pros: Complete benefits package and you can't beat free tuition for salaried employees! Might as well go for that Masters while working full-time (even if it takes you several years).
cons: Very little wiggle room when it comes to promotions (within your department - but WSU chooses from within across departments, so that's a plus) and raises - WSU has a strict policy for moving up both in title and pay. The pay bumps are also negligible, so negotiate for that max salary if offered the position.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Detroit, MI
pros: Great college culture, good people who are humble and very willing to help. The area around campus is really improving and thriving with an energy wonderful to be around.
cons: On the lower end of the pay scale but decent benefits. Parking in and around campus is still an issue at times and much needed building upgrades are beginning to come to fruition a la the Student Center. Many more buildings and rest rooms still require renovations.

pros: Up to 5 classes free in a year,  wellness warriors that pays 250 a year for just going to workouts and seminars on campus during work shift.   Culture is nice really family oriented m definitely not the corporate life.
cons: No real opportunity of vertical movement due to people retiring late.  Hard to get undergraduate classes completed if you working because the classes are usually in the day.  Try talking with supervisor to see if you can work over so you can go to class.

review_title: It was great experience. I've learned a lot.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Detroit, MI
pros: Friendly people, nice working environment. Everybody has been so helpful, and the teachers and classes were set well. I like the lab rotation in the first year, which helps me decide which lab I'd like to pursue for my degree.
cons: The class list is limited - not diversified. Many state-of-art technologies are not offered in class. Students are kinda separate from job market. Not many opportunities for students to gain experience before graduation, thus it was difficult for them to find a good job. Also, the academic communication between Wayne State and other schools are not active.

pros: Leeway with curriculum for competency courses, friendly, supportive environment, parking reimbursement.
cons: Only part time and therefore low pay and no benefits, you never know what your schedule will be (or if you'll have a job) from semester to semester, can be difficult to teach for some of the less competent professors, none of the benefits of being a student or a full time WSU employee (tuition assistance, gym access, etc.)

review_title: If you have a relative in high places? you are good.
job_title: Network Engineer I in Detroit, MI
pros: Excellent Benefits package.  If you have a relative or family member who works there, you get promoted easily (you also get your job this way).
cons:
Nepotism and cronyism are king at Wayne State.  You get ahead by being close, CLOSE friends with colleages, and superiors.  People's relatives are frequently hired after "mandatory" interview process (but only the relative was going to actually be hired).
Poor, Poor management of people. Most managers have NO management training. Most managers have never worked outside of the University.  Most don't have a clue how to treat people.
Tenured managers are even more difficult because they can openly abuse staff and their academic superiors can't and won't do anything about it.

job_title: Help Desk Supervisor in Detroit, MI
pros: Understanding immediate bosses, Continuous professional development, Options to work on many different projects, Different forms of compensation (e.g. housing paid for)
cons: Not many options for moving up, Higher departments make decisions (that sound good to them on paper) over smaller ones when they do not understand the smaller departments, Limited to the number of hours that we can work when we are in school also

review_title: Pluses and Many Minuses of Wayne State
pros: Great campus location, good culture, friendly personnel, decent library facilities, good website and course management and communication/email system. Up amd coming university.
cons: Parking can be difficult to find and meters only allow 2 hour maximum, need to make more adjunct faculty permanent to provide stability and continuity especially in the undergraduate programs, horrible student retention and graduation rates because of this lack of stable and permanent instructors and too much focus on research and only lipservice on teaching.

pros: Wayne State has an excellent  health care, dental, and vision package with very affordable rates. Wayne State also offers a generous time-off package to full time employees as well as discounts to many mid-town retail establishments and eateries.
cons: The university has been drastically eliminating jobs without warning while executive administrative salaries have been increasing constantly. The unions are weak and good work is often left unnoticed. The political environment is steep  and nepotism runs rampant. Promotions are given based on association rather than ability more often than not.

pros: Each day I have different tasks and often have to learn new and interesting skills to complete said tasks. It was the perfect opportunity to work in addition to being a student and it greatly enhanced my undergraduate experience.
cons: Sometimes there can be gaps between projects where there is not much to accomplish. I felt like I was wasting my time when I wanted to be working.

job_title: Office Service Clerk in Detroit, MI
pros:
Great Benefits - double contribution to retirement
Good People - Work with good people in all departments
Respected employer - Working here will allow you to meet a lot of different people.
cons:
Pays less than other Universities in some positions. 
Located in Detroit so if that makes you nervous then don't apply. 
Snobby about education.  Education valued over experience.

review_title: Overall, it was a great way to earn easy money but not useful in the long run
job_title: General Office Clerk in Detroit, MI
pros: You meet a lot of important individuals working at Wayne State, you can use these connections to make your life at Wayne State much much less difficult than it needs to be.
cons: After you have graduated the school id essentially not interested in you one bit. Their only contact with you will be to donate back money.

review_title: Wayne is great to work overall, but watch out for certain departments!
pros:
-Decent benefits
-Some flexibility in schedule
-Plenty of time banks to choose from 
-Tuition assistance program is second to none
cons:
-I work in a department where management is subpar at best
-No room for growth, once you get in, it can be difficult to move around
-Must pay for parking
-Area is a little sketchy at times, esp. after 5:00 pm

review_title: Learned a lot, but a borderline-hostile work environment
pros: It's a large, urban university with a lot of clout in the city of Detroit. It's also centrally located near downtown.
cons: The negative vibe among the staff -- from the top to the bottom -- is palpable. It's hard to get anything done, particularly when you're trying to work with other departments. Turf wars are a fact of life here.

review_title: Bureaucratic university with too little faculty governance
pros: Good facilities, union, nice campus and good facilities
cons: Overly bureaucratic, union, lack of funding for conference travel & minor research costs.  Too much power in administrative positions and too little in the hands of the faculty as a whole, or as a department.

pros: Good benefits, decent paid time off, free tuition for employees, discounted tuition for their families.
cons: Administrative staff has been cut drastically over the last 6 years.  Individuals are expected to perform the work of two people for the same amount of money. Yet faculty continues to grow.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Detroit, MI
pros: I was a graduate research teaching assistant for 3 years and I was given many exciting opportunities to learn and advance in my studies. Everyone is very nice and there is always someone who is willing to go an extra mile to help you.
cons: Pay is on the lower side - the air conditioning and heating need some work - it's very hard to work in these conditions, sometimes.

job_title: Wood/Metal Shop Technician in Detroit, MI
pros: I was a student at Wayne State University for 5 years, and an employee for 2. I worked in both the metal and wood shops at University, mostly so I had unlimited access to the shops for personal use.
cons: There is no woodshop requirement (safety class, basic wood working, etc.) before using their woodshop services, which is not a smart policy to have in place.

review_title: Excellent pay & benefits, but toxic work environment
pros: Excellent benefits, salary, tuition remission, and wellness warrior program
cons: Highly political!  Management (at least in my department) does not interact openly with employees. There is a high level of dissatisfaction with work environment among employees.  Not many opportunities to advance.  Those that do advance seem to get there by who they know, not by proven strong work ethic.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Detroit, MI
pros: Access to good mentors if motivated.
cons: Poor stipend support for Ph.D. students. 20K is among lowest (bottom quartile) in nation for science. Comparable schools provide thousands more.  Department (in school of medicine) has too many tenured professors with no funding and poor publishing records. Little career support for non academic research paths. Faculty is stuck in a 60-70's era mentality. 1 in 5 will actually work in academia. Department leadership is lacking and typically the graduate officer is appointed to a non-productive professor. The current graduate officer only has 3 publications within the past 5 years. Overall, while the department holds itself in high esteem it requires massive improvements. I recommend prospective graduate students seek other institutions for graduate training.

review_title: I loved working here while I was in school
pros: I loved working with the people I worked with, hours were extremely flexible, nice way to build up your portfolio, laid back atmosphere, the customers were either new or were regulars
cons: You have to pay for parking, traffic after work was bad, sometimes had to do other people's jobs to make sure they were done in a timely fashion, no room to grow after graduation

pros: The university is a great place to work.  They have great benefits (vacation time, insurance, tuition help). Good programs to help you in your career.
cons: Though they are in education, too many people with less school have been promoted over me even though they started after I did.  It's  not what you know, but who you know.

review_title: Being a Resident Advisor at Wayne State
pros: There is a great family environment here at Wayne State. You always feel secure in knowing that the people you work with are there when you need them.
cons: You are always under a microscope. This is not a personal problem for me. However, people complain about this aspect of my job.

pros: There are a lot of facilities if you love to do research. Specially in fundamental science. Very talented faculty with many collaborations with national and international labs.
cons: Moving to the next level will take many years since the opportunities are not that high. Sometimes working with front office administrative staff is a pain.

pros: There are various of cultures here. The salary is good for Michigan and the school has pretty good safety management. For example, you can ask a policeman to watch you home if you have to work late. The medical benifits here are good too.
cons: Not a good place if you want to take a walk after dinner. The winter here is long with lots of snow.  Not too much fun place nearby

review_title: I had a great experience working at Wayne State.
job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Detroit, MI
pros: There are a lot of opportunities. You have lot of room to move and grow to meet your own benefits. Overall great place to work.
cons: A big time commitment. If you are a student with a busy schedule you will have to learn how to manage your time very well.

pros: Very friendly people and staff. Also, weekly free food and also the timing are very flexible.Wok life balance is too good. There is no compulsion of dress code, and the cultures is too good.
cons: The wage is little less. Could have given little more wages , rest everything is good and also fine. Sometimes there is no assuriety of the pass, as it is on call appointment kind of thing

review_title: In all, worthwhile... but the bad outweighs the good.
job_title: Help Desk Supervisor in Detroit, MI
pros: The benefits are excellent, and working on a university campus is especially fun.
cons: There is no vision. The politics between divisions and colleges is insane. Too many people are too concerned about getting their piece of the pie and not attempting to make everything work together. It is, in the end, a very toxic environment with management that has no clue how to handle its employees.

review_title: PhD Student of Industrial Organizational Psychology
pros: The Professors are excellent, and the funding is available for all years in which taking classes is mandatory.
cons: Advisers to PhD students are removed from the health and well-being of their students. It does not seem to be a priority.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Detroit, MI
pros: Most positions allow flexible hours. Wayne State provides a health insurance program including dental and eye insurance. Tuition coverage is guaranteed by the university for a minimum 1.5 years if enrolled as a PhD student.
cons: Work-life balance can be difficult. No defined vacation time. Workload is PI dependent. Lack of departmental funding can limit the research opportunity.

pros: The benefits are are excellent! The benefits include the university doubling what you percentage you choose to invest.
cons: The Cons are that the their are huge issues relating to diversity and inclusion relating to employees at the university and student. There is especially drop and low enrollment for minority students.

pros: Wayne State University is a unique place to work due to its diverse workforce and amicable environment. Acting as an anchoring institution for the city of Detroit, this university provides a great work experience and perspective for the overall benefit of its community.
cons: There are no downsides of working at Wayne State University other than its location being in the City of Detroit. Due to public schools problem, family with children may not want to live near the area.

pros: Wonderful colleagues and supportive staff. Wayne is in a great location and is making huge strides in certain research areas and I am proud to be a part of that.
cons: Far too many administrative positions. Projects, requests, etc are all typically delayed due to going through so many channels. Too many office staff leads to high school type of drama and conflict. It can be very silly.

review_title: Great place to work and study
pros: Wayne State is a great employer, who makes sure their students schedules are fitted to their work schedules so that they don't get over loaded, or have to miss either.
cons: You will find yourself spending your entire day on campus every day.  Not exactly the college experience people hope for.  Also, no benefits.

review_title: A good place to be in ...
pros: Research intensive, good courses, good on-campus accommodation, dedicated faculty, location advantage, flexible, evening classes really convenient, great scope for self improvement
cons: A bit expensive, no scholarships awarded at all, campus can be improved, Some TAs are not good, sport activities can be improved.

pros: The job itself was really cool, great experience, my supervisor was incredible to work with.
cons: The payroll was almost always messed up my first 2 years working there. First-year working there I was owed 6 paychecks, and it took a year to get them, and countless meetings and proof of account statements. Don't ever expect pay raises, as I was promised 3 and never actually got any of them.

review_title: Never really sure who had my back and who held the knife.
job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Detroit, MI
pros: Great benefits, like 403(b) match where employee contributes 5% and WSU matches with 10%, and FSAs for health and dependent care. Also had a lot of flexibility in choosing to work from home or office whenever feasible.
cons: Dean of the College was a cold-hearted, manipulative idiot. Parking is expensive and either dilapidated or under major construction. Street parking at your own risk.

pros: Retirement matching is excellent, as are the choices of health benefits. Good place to get experience. 100% tuition reimbursment is great to further your education.
cons: Hard to move up, but sometimes able to move "diagonally" across schools or divisions. Union bumping rights, even in professional positions, causes too many disruptions and lowers morale. Performance bonus increase freezes for the past five years leads to doing bare minimum work in many cases.

review_title: I'm working as a graduate teaching assistant,Great place to teach.Big diversity.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Ssistant in Detroit, MI
pros: We were give proper teaching training with seminars, orientations and weekly meetings.The administration is helpful.I can organize my classes as I wish.The ggrading procedure is also up to me.So I like that in-dependency.
cons: The department I was teaching is not too big,But it equipped with all the required facilities.Salary is not really good.It's hard to reschedule the classes you are teaching in case of an emergency.

pros: The school of Education and Social Work are top notch. Great 401k plans and located in a great area.
cons: The School not about students, antiquated in regards to student success. Not enough people that think outside of the box. Failing black and brown students.

review_title: A place with true work-life balance
pros: Wayne State has very good benefit package and provides real work-life balance for its employees. It is a great place to work for if salary and career growth are not your top considerations.
cons: Low salary and not many career growth opportunities as it tends to hire external candidates for management positions. Too strong union presence. Too heavy- headed with fewer working bees to do real work.

review_title: Research drive is good, but utilities are a bit lacking.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Detroit, MI
pros: The culture is very nice.  Advisors are very supporting and helpful.  The other graduate students are community oriented and friendly.
cons: Detroit regularly has power and other utility problems.  Coordination between different branches is very poor, so it can be hard to get things fixed properly.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Detroit, MI
pros:
Wayne State University has lots of pros:
1) The only university in the area that offers a variety of majors and degrees.
2) Has a lots of finding resources that is very important for student who intend their research to be funded.
3) Its campus is very safe because it is located in Detroit area.
cons: They are very few and they are not very significant like sharing offices with others.

pros: Get to enjoy helping people every night. Being able to perform all duties with little to no supervision. Great work atmosphere.
cons: Sometimes customers are intoxicated. Rude and can become hostile. And with little to no supervision I'm required to handle mostly all situations myself.

pros: This is a good group of people to work with for the most part.  Very competent and friendly coworkers.  Enjoyable to work with them.
cons: Very little job security if you're not tenured.  There have been major cutbacks recently during the current economic crisis in the state.

pros:
Accessibility of fitness equipment and showers. 
Lots of activities & information is available at the front desk, leading you to be more in-the-loop with campus events.
cons:
Leadership does not invest much time/effort into employee satisfaction and seems to have very little tolerance/respect for student employees.
Time off is tough to come by unless you set your availability before you start working there
You can bet on not making a penny over minimum wage here.

review_title: Great Benefits - Lack of Business Strategy
job_title: Academic Services Officer II in Detroit, MI
pros: Benefits are awesome, people are awesome
cons: Working for PhDs who have zero business acumen does not contribute to high morale. Tenure makes PhDs out of touch with reality. High level administrators make way too much money for what they do.

review_title: Wayne State is a great place to work.
pros: They are a family orientated place of employment where they value every employee.  Their benefit package is great, they aid in paying your tuition and your family's.
cons: There is not a lot of opportunity for growth within the organization.  Most departments work to help their employees grow, but there are not a lot of job openings in which to move.

review_title: World-class experience working along side some of the greatest minds from around the world.
pros: Staff and students from all corners of the globe unified as one warrior family across hundreds of disciplines driving Wayne State to the forefront in many sectors.
cons: Some departments express a strong micromanagement system that inhibits the expression of new and potentially innovative processes.

review_title: The best part time job for a student.
job_title: Campus Tour Guide in Detroit, MI
pros: Flexible hours and a chance to brush up on people skills. Learned a lot about the university, as well as learning how to deal with crowds of people
cons:
Not too much room for growth and pay was a little less than to be desired. 
Management also changes fairly frequently so new policies and rules can be added at the drop of a hat.

job_title: ABET Project Coordinator in Detroit, MI
pros: Its a very motivating environment which welcomes new ideas and contributions. It pays well and management is very understanding and has high level of hospitality.
cons: There's lot of bureaucracy and paper work existing in the system. All these collectively contribute to time wasting which is highly unneeded.

review_title: An awesome place to study and work simultaneously
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Detroit, MI
pros: An awesome place to study and work simultaneously. Even after being a GRA in the department of Civil and Environmental Engineering during my Masters program in Electrical Engineering, I was able to balance the study and research work.
cons: Apart from the weather perspective which becomes really cold during winter and stays like that even during March also, I think everything else is rally good.

pros:
Competitive salary and benefit. 
SOME collegial colleagues.
SOME qualified faculty.
Will get the chance to work alone; nobody will bother you because nobody comes to school
cons:
No sense of direction at the department level and at the school level. 
Bad quality of education
Poor quality of students
Complacent attitude by tenured faculty - half of them only show up to teach their evening class (Partly perhaps because the main campus is located in Detroit, and faculty generally live as far away from Detroit as possible)

review_title: Fantastically structure Police Department that is Connected to its' Community
pros: Pay is great. Benefits are wonderful. Team morale is awesome. Training is given to everyone and the department has the means to send their officers and dispatchers to training in other states.
cons: communication between shift supervisors is sometimes lacking.

review_title: It's alright. I could do better
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Detroit, MI
pros: Many opportunities are there. In some labs quality of research is high. But compared to other big universities Wayne state lacks the cutting edge research.
cons: You can only jump so hight here. No matter how hard you work there is a limitation on how far you could reach in terms of research publications due to low funding.

pros: Afforded tuition-free education. Completed Bachelors and Masters degrees while employed full-time.
cons: Mid-Management inadequately trained. Most are hired based on WHO they know, not WHAT they know. Lots of managers, very few support staff. Most support staff overworked, doing more than one job, or doing work outside of their classification.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Detroit, MI
pros: The university is big, had chances to access many materials, time is flexible as well
cons: Environment is not so pleasant, you have to coordinate a lot things yourself, hard to find a living place near the university as well

review_title: I learned a lot initially but kept doing the same things
pros: Learned to think on my own and problem solve as an undergraduate. Very, very flexible hours. They completely cater around your schedule.
cons: Incredibly tedious after your first couple months.

pros: There are many perks to working in Detroit. The campus is well kept and Corktown area is nice! It is a great place to work if you go to school there.
cons: Know where to go and where not to go. Obviously don't work out to your car at night alone. There is security who will safely escort you to your vehicle.

pros:
as an Admin, you really get a lot of experience in a variety of capacities ; 

NOTE: this is only for the PRB, NOT WSU as a whole. WSU employment is amazing.
cons: ridiculously archaic and toxic environment - NOT healthy in the least. Also administrative support staff will almost never be transferred from their temporary positions w/ Computech (or whichever contract house)

pros: Great Benefits - Flexible schedule
cons: Horrible work culture. People who are working hard usually get the crappy end of the stick while the incompetent managers get praised. Toxic work environment on most days. When you try to fix something that is wrong, you get no help from HR. Upper management can not make decisions in a timely manner, always blaming someone else for stuff.

review_title: Great Learning experience and view into life as an academic
pros: I had the opportunity to learn what is was like to play a role in funded scientific research. With guidance from professors, I was able to help develop a procedure and carry out an experiment that was a part of a larger project.
cons: There are very limited opportunities for scientific research assistants outside of the medical field.

review_title: Wayne State provides endless opportunities for its students and faculty.
pros: There is always something happening at Wayne. It is in the heart of the city and the opportunities at the university are endless.
cons: I would change the hours that available to be. i worked under a budgets so there was a limit to the amount of hours I could work.

review_title: Wayne State does not provide good support to enable outstanding performance
pros: As an academic I have total freedom to pick my research area and the manner in which I teach my courses
cons: Wayne State provides no support to implement innovative programs. If anything there are numerous organizational barriers to launch any initiative. In addition the financial and legal bureaucracy is generally unhelpful.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Farmington Hills, MI
pros: Good Health Plans. Moderate Salary, Wide variety of benefits including tuition fee discount for employee & wife. Very diverse
cons: Limited progress opportunities, large and slow bureaucratic structure, low level of negotiability. Limited quality-based bouns

job_title: Talent Management Coordinator in Detroit, MI
pros: Benefits are pretty good zero decuctable medical plans and the HMO plans are reasonably priced for a family. I liked most of my co-workers.
cons: Paying $50 bi-weekly for parking, Position was stressful, poor management, negative enviornment. Management was horrible with no regard to your time. Advertised as a 37.5 hour work week, you will end up working well over 40.

pros: Very accepting to people from diverse backgrounds. There is a lot of culture and respect in the work environment and you get to learn a lot. Downtown is just down the street!
cons: Can get a little dull over time. The campus life is a little dead, especially in winters. You have to look for things to do.

job_title: Tutor and Mentor In Science and Mathematics in Detroit, MI
pros: It is a good opportunity to provide guidance, tutor, mentor students towards higher education. In my own personal growth involves improvements in fundamentals, teamwork, public speaking, communication, leadership, verbal and written skills, presentation skills, recent fast-growing technology from upcoming generation.
cons: I am not aware of any cons from this job in my opinion.

review_title: Great people, great opportunities and professional development, little job security
pros: The people in my department are solid, there's initiative to be supportive of students and the surrounding community, and there's plenty happening already to sink your teeth into as well as interest from others to try something.
cons: Job stability for lecturers was non existent and unfortunately compounded by Covid.

job_title: Master Carpenter/Shop Supervisor in Detroit, MI
pros: The Theatre & Dance dept provided great and up-to-date equipment in a large shop area where nearly all scenic pieces can be set up. Located in the heart of downtown Detroit, there are plenty of fantastic places to eat and socialize.
cons: The commute to certain venues can be a slight pain to get to.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Detroit, MI
pros: With hard work, you can earn a degree at Wayne State. If staying within the metro detroit area it is one the accredited university you can attend.
cons: Wayne State Associate Dean of Graduate Programs recently announced higher stipend support for School of Medicine graduate students. However, support is not increasing because the overall length of stipend is decreasing. It is a financial maneuver meant to convey increased support.  If going into the sciences/research it is better to choose another regional university over Wayne State.

pros: Great benefits and work life balance. Slow pace and no overtime.
cons: Slow pace and nothing happens quickly. Management is very mediocre as they seem to have a problem with talent retention. The level of pay is ridiculous and the union presence really puts a damper on overall motivation.

review_title: loved the research, while it was still in its glory
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Detroit, MI
pros: Cutting-edge research, innovation, great people working at least in my department
cons: Too much politics!  New management is limiting the growth of new research

job_title: Academic Service Officer III and Director in Detroit, MI
pros: Tuition reimbursement, great 401k plan and great location.
cons: Very weak diversity in upper management, limited true community engagement and terrible student support programming.

job_title: Senior Data Warehouse Specialist & Data Architect in Detroit, MI
pros: Great company, great pay, I highly recommend it.  Love t Love it  Love it.
cons: Not much cons.   Benefits should be better.  Better insurance  Better PTO, better, better better

pros: working with students, being in a fun environment, challenging, room to progress.
cons: a lot of office politics, faculty and staff bicker amongst one another and involve everyone, not everyone has your back, a lot of backstabbing.

pros:
Was having a great experience to work with so nice people. 
Learned a lot of new things. 
I was a part of Survey Research Unit Performing Telephonic Interviews.
Maintaining confidential records of the interviewed persons.
Communicating with different type of people
And enjoyed every part of my job
